name: Minister of Religion Accommodation
short_description: Property held for occupation by minister of religion

notice_requirement.timing: Before or at start of tenancy
notice_requirement.content: Notice must state possession may be recovered under Ground 5
notice_requirement.exception: Court may dispense if just and equitable

property_holding.purpose: For occupation by minister of religion
property_holding.evidence: Trust deed, church ownership documents, diocesan records

current_requirement.need: Requires dwelling for residence in performing religious duties
current_requirement.employer: Minister must be employed by holder of property or organization

notice_period.court_proceedings: Can be started after notice expires

evidence_required: Written notice given at tenancy start
Proof of property ownership by religious organization
Trust deed or church documents showing purpose
Evidence minister requires accommodation (employment contract, church appointment letter)

high_probability: Clear written notice at tenancy start
Property clearly held for religious purposes
Genuine minister appointed and requires accommodation
medium_probability: Property ownership by religious organization provable but documentation limited
Minister's need is genuine but alternative accommodation may exist
low_probability: No notice given and court refuses to dispense
Cannot prove property held for religious purposes
Religious organization has other suitable properties

red_flags: No written notice given at start
Property not owned by religious organization
No trust deed or evidence of religious purpose
No minister appointed or requiring accommodation
Claim appears to be pretext for eviction

costs.legal_costs: £1,000-£2,500 if represented (often borne by religious organization)

tenant_defenses: No notice given and no good reason to dispense
Property not held for religious purposes
Religious organization has other suitable properties
notes: Ground 5 is MANDATORY but very rarely used. Most common with Church of England and Catholic Church properties. Strict requirements on proving religious purpose and minister's need.
case_law: Diocese of Southwark v Coker [1998] - Religious purpose must be established
Archbishop of Canterbury v Williamson [1991] - Minister's need must be genuine and immediate
